content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
												This is a great Squad Tactics, turn based strategy. When you load up a game, it'll ask you to make a Squad. First you choose what kind of Special Forces you want your dudes to be: US Navy Seals, Germany's KSK, Canada’s JTF2, UK's SAS, and if you get the DLC, you can play as the Green Frozen Synapse guys too. After that, you choose each one of your 4 guys portrait/face, which is pretty limited, and their class, such as weapon expert, medic, direct assault, etc., which governs what kind of skills you can use in game and what kind of passives they have. You can name your squad too.Once you're in the game, you have your squad move through the level eliminating terrorists. If you've ever played Frozen Synapse, moving around and killing is like that, but less in-depth. Click where you want to move, and where you want him to face when he get's there. You can click along his path and have him look in a different direction when he get's there. You can also have them throw grenades and other equipment if you've purchased them(more on this in a bit). You do this with all 4 squad members, click 'breach', which starts the turn, and they'll all do their orders immediately, shooting at enemies that enter their line of site. A 'turn' is pretty much 5 seconds, and clicking Breach will have them carry out orders and shoot people for 5 seconds before time stops and you can issue another set of orders Some have skills and passives, like the Weapons Expert has 'Suppressive Fire', which does what it says. The Intelligence class can see all around them, a 360° range of vision for a fairly short distance, about 5 feet. Normally, a soldier has  the standard 40°-45° cone line of sight in front of them(no distance restrictions), simulating a person's eyesight. The Intelligence class has this stanard 45° cone, plus a much smaller 360° view, which extends maybe 10-ish feet. This is great for when an enemy is in a place you didn't expect. Normally a soldier will turn around by himself and shoot back at an enemy that shot him, but that's a precious few seconds of getting wailed on. The 360° view let's the Intelligence class immediately start to turn around the second he enters his range. You'll still get hit since you'll still have to turn around, but the chance of dying has been drastically lowered.After each mission you get money, experience, and a 1-4 Star rating depending on how well you did,  Experience will level up a soldier, and when he levels, you can put 5 points into one of their stats. Each class has some stats all on their own, like the Intelligence Class has a stat that increases his 360° view distance. All Classes have some similar stats though, like all have a 'Moving Speed(distance you can travel in one turn). 'Accuracy', 'Health', and 'Reaction', which is how long it takes for them to 'lock on' to the enemy and start shooting. All stats can be increased to 100, and each stat starts at around 45-55. The type of squad, such as US Seals/German KSK/UK SAS/etc, plays in here too. Each type has a beginning bonus to one of their stats. I believe either the US Rangers or Seals starts with their Accuracy at 75. Each squad type has a bonus, and that bonus can pretty much aid in your preferred play style.As for money, You get a $200-ish bonus for completing a mission for the first time, and I think $200 per Star(rating), at least on normal difficulty(4 modes). There are other bonuses and penalties that reward/subtract too. Anyway, in the main menu there's a Marketplace, where you can buy new clothes, armor, helmets, weapons, all sorts of weapon attachments, and consumable items. Most of these items will offer some sort stat boost, like scopes increasing accuracy and armor(vests) increasing health. This isn't Door Kickers btw, where buying the gun once unlocks it for free use with everyone else. If you want your 4 squad members to wield that shiny rifle, then you'll need to buy that shiny rifle 4 times. I wasn't  mocking Door Kickers btw. I love that game too. If you're short on cash, and there's a particular level you like, you can simply do that level a few times to earn money. Just keep in mind that you'll only really earn money for the amount of stars you get on that run(4 max). So at most, on normal difficulty at least, you can only get $800 max, and you'll probably have some of that subtracted due to taking damage or taking too long. The prices are not ridiculous btw. They're not expensive, but you won't be buying everything in the first hour(or week).There are a good number of missions to do, and lots of gear and weapons to get and play around with. I definitely recommend this game.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2015
												Here's my review for, Breach & Clear !! **Early Review (2h gametime)** (7.6 out of 10.0) Overall.Before you start reading (this review is kinda long) you can just take a look at my screenshots to see what this game is about.http://steamcommunity.com/id/xDMikeW2k14/screenshots/?appid=266130&sort=newestfirst&browsefilter=myfiles&view=imagewallNow to my review :First Look: I didn't know what I'm about to witness of playing this game because I don't play simulator games so much. And especially tactical simulators.My first run was near 2 hours. I enjoyed this game and played the first mission, 5 times.This game has very much to offer in terms of difficulties,missions,equippments,replayability,roles and ofcourse the main reason we purchae this game - tactics.Gameplay: Gameplay is very simple once you get used to it (I got used to it very fast and the tutorial was short and clear).You have 4 characters, each one has same options and your role is to control them.Besides that, there is the map itself which has easy acess to it (all you need to do is to move the cameras to your like, and manovering the soldiers on the map.)Me as a hardcore tactical fan player I like to complete each mission on the best side so it took me around 15-20 minutes to complete a mission but after you do the same mission few times you do it faster and easier, and while still enjoying the mission. (8/10)Cons: 1) Repetetive. 2) Full Members each mission (Annoying thing is you can only use all 4 members and not 2 or 1 or 3.)Gameplay Styles: 1) Go loud and use breaching equippment / Loud weapons / Frag grenades etc2) Go quiet and use silencers / lock picks / Flashbangs etc3) Split your team through the rooms or work with all of them togather in each room.4) Enjoy your time in investing and planning each mission to your liking and your own tactical strategy.5) Difficulties - 5 Difficulties. (8.5/10)Graphics: Only saw one map so far but each room looks realistic with objects and tactical props (Walls/Big Closets etc that can block the A.I view so you can take cover behind them). (5/10)Cons: 1) Lack of FPS. I get this is a sim game but they did add fps moments but I'm not feeling it cuz it's only in start/end of the mission. it would be better if we could switch between FPS and Map-Look modes of the cameras but oh well I guess it will take the tactical-strategy element of this game.Equippment:What can I say about this one.. 4 Sections - Weapons , Gear , Headset , Consumeables.There is an in-game store (Buy/Sell items from the money you've earned in each mission).In each section there are many things to buy include Vests/Guns/Gun Parts/Suit Colours/Camos/Grenades etc..Some of them are locked, you need to unlock them as you progress through the game.There are also stats like Speed/Accuracy/Noise etc in some of the equippments. (7/10)Cons: A bit more organized menu would be better, and there are some items I don't think I will use.RPG Elements:I should talk about this one cuz there are 6-7 special op teams you can choose from.6 Roles to choose from and stick them to your soldier. (Not sure yet if each team has different roles or not)Stats in equippment items and Money to invest in equippment.Level up system to your soldiers. + XP.Choose how your soldier will look like, and colour your guns. (6/10)Enjoyment: (9/10) I'm sorry but this is one of the best tacticla simulators I've played.. I can invest all my time in this game figouring out different tactics/ways to approach into the enemy.Repetetive: (6/10) It is but still you enjoy playing this game.Replayability (9/10)Frustraiton (1/10) - Early review but as long as you know what you do in this game.. You're fine.Boredom (0/10) - Nothing so far.

content:
Posted: March 24, 2014
												Das Spiel ist eine gute Grundlage benötigt aber deutliche verbesserungen. Man kann auch sagen solide Basis, ausbaufähig. Im Grunde ist alles dabei was ein taktisches Spiel benötigt. Fangen wir mit dem offensichtlichen an:Grafik: Gemessen an den heutigen Grafikblendern mit bombastischen Effekten aber null Story kann das Spiel nicht mit halten. Die Frage ist jedoch ob es das überhaupt muss. Die Antwort ist nein. Das Spiel hat eine vollkommen ausreichende Grafik die natürlich auch vor dem Hintergrund betrachtet werden muss das das Spiel aus dem Mobile Umfeld geported wude. Sie ist recht schlicht aber dennoch vollkommen ausreichend um das nötige so darzustellen ohne das man gleich Augenschmerzen bekommt. Jedoch muss man sagen das es für Leute die nur auf aussehen Wert legen eine Fehlinvestition ist,Was sitzt neben den Augen? Richtig, die Ohren....Sound:Der Sound ist ebenso wie die Grafik recht simpel gehalten. Hier hätte ich mir einen etwas voluminöseren Sound gewünscht. Oft hören sich gerade die Waffen wie kleine Knallerbsen an. Die Umgebungsounds sind faktisch nicht vorhanden und auch sonst kommt nicht viel Abwechslung auf wenn man seine Operator durch die Level jagt. Um eine wirkliche immersion zu erschaffen und den Spieler eintauchen zu lassen in die Welt der SOF´s wäre eine tiefergehende Soundkulisse wünschenswert.Spielmechanik:Das Konzept dieses Spiels ist irgendwie rundenbasiertes point & click. Wer allerdings ein neues  JA erwartet wird wohl ein wenig entäuscht sein. Im Grunde hat man nicht allzu viele aktionen zur Auswahl. Der Vorteil darin liegt dann sicherlich das man recht schnell in das Spiel findet. Das Tutorial erklärt kurz, knackig ausreichend die Steuerung so das man nicht erst ein ewig langes Tutorial absolvieren muss um endlich loslegen zu können. Man merkt dem Spiel eben seine Herkunft an. Für den OC hätte man hier sicher noch einiges rausholen können. Z.B. kann man zu beginn eines Levels Zugangsladungen oder die Schrottflinte nutzen um Türen zu öffnen. Danach geht das nicht mehr, zumal auch alle Türen auf sind. Man hat zwar ein Dietrich aber keine Entry Tools wie das Haligan etc. Das Spiel wirkt dann oft ein wenig lieblos und gerade in Bezug auf den das Intro in dem es als das Trainingstool für Spezialeinheiten vorgstellt wird kommt man sich ein wenig veralbert vor. Das Ausrüsten der Operator ist manchmal ein wenig umständlich dafür kann man aber jeden Operator anders konfigurieren so das keiner aussieht wie der anderen usw. Jeder Charackter hat ein Levelsystem. Wenn man hoch Levelt bekommt man Fähigkeitspunkte mit denen man die Jungs trainieren kann. Zusätzlich werden alle paar Stufen spezielle Features freigeschaltetContent:Der Inhalt ist für den Preis vollkommen ok. Man hat eine gute Auswahl an Level und Ausrüstung. Alle Level kann man in 3 Modi spielen. Die Level sind in "Kampangen" verpackt die nach Ländern geordnet sind. Jedes Land hat 5 Level. Dabei sind u.a A-Stan, Deutschland, Mexiko, Komlumbien, China, Türkei. Die Level weisen verschiedene Schwierigkeitsgrade auf und haben unterschiedlich Ausmaße. Die Levelgröße hat auch Einfluss auf die Ausrüstung die Eingesetzt werden sollte Die Ausrüstung die man zur Verfügung hat unterteilt sich in Waffen, Waffenzubehör, Bekleidung, verbrauchbare Ausrüstung und Körperschutz. Hier gibt es dann auch nochmalige unterteilungen. Jedes Stück equipment kostet im Spiel verdientes Geld. Somit kann man mit der Zeit seine Chars immer bessere Ausrüstung kaufen usw. Die Operator kann man aus verschiedenen Gruppierungen nutzen. Jede Einheit hat ihre Vor- und Nachteile. Der Rest ist dann eben persönliche Vorliebe, Wie man sieht ist der Umfang durchaus angemessen für den Preis.Fazit:Das spiel ist für alle taktiker von interesse. Man sollte jedoch nicht zu viel erwarten denn es wird schnell eintönig da einfach zu wenig möglichkeiten bestehen. Vielleicht sehen wir im zweiten Teil, insofern es einen gibt, ein paar verbesserungen die hier eben noch fehlen. Noch wirkt das Spiel an vielen stellen zu steril und gleichmässig. Leider gibt es auch keine Informationen zwecks der Modbarkeit. Wir lassen uns überraschen. MFG

content:
Posted: October 14, 2014
												Very polished tactical shooter in vain of Frozen Synapse. Decent customization even though the weapon and gear models look too similar. The weapons are balanced and there are several nice levels which can be enjoyed in 3 modes: Terrorist hunt (kill everybody), Bomb Defusal, survival/escape. Graphics are decent but not eye-popping. Far from it, actually. The human models all look pretty much the same even if you select different characters. Mediocre at best and could have used a more vivid style and color palette. The gameplay itself is turn based tactical battles. about 70% of the maps are indoors and use tight corridors and covers to keep the action pumping and the rest are outdoors which focus more on tactical play and choosing the best ways to strike.Your squad of 4 (which you can create yourself and customize) level up as you gain more stars in missions and more XP. You also receive money to purchase new weapon upgrades and gear. You choose specifically which attribute to level up for each soldier (e.g. accuracy, speed, special ability, reaction etc.). This all helps to give the game longevity as well as harder difficulty settings which make the game much more demanding. I'd also like to note that the music is pretty cool.I only wish there was a "Restart Level" button in the pause menu because you need to go back to the main menu every time you choose to restart a level mid play.All in all, a great bargain game and I'd say it's worth the full price even though there aren't many maps to play around in (there are new ones in a DLC though). But if you liked Frozen Synapse or want to give the games a try I think you'll like what you find here.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2014
												Shallow and greatly unpractical gameplay. The PC version of this game looks like it was made for tablets. Coordinating your squad members' actions proved to be quite difficult and limited. Here are some features of the game:  Your tactical options for each soldier in a turn are:      -Moving the soldier (you can set multiple waypoints and also choose between moving quickly or carefully);      -Choosing on each waypoint where the soldier will be looking at;      -Telling the soldier to hold his position;      -Using the soldiers' special ability;      -Checking intel on the enemy.So far, your options are quite limited, but that is not inherently bad. Sometimes, a small array of options may be backed up by a great gaming experience. Now that's this game's undoing. The AI is almost as smart as real person... if said person was blindfolded and told to find a way out of a maze made of death lasers that made noise so they could still be avoided... and even so the person decided to run and hug death.Coordinating your team's actions proved to be quite the challenge when you can't even tell one of your soldiers to take another soldier's position; you can't tell them to hold fire or to focus one specific enemy; if you tell a soldier move up to a door, he will immediatelly open it! Now THAT'S some real tactical decision right there, phew. Did you make a mistake while placing one of your waypoints? No problem! You just need to press the undo button and remove every subsequent waypoint you had set untill you delete the single one that was wrong... and now place them all again! (I guess the game does that so you don't lose track of what you had in mind...)Every time you select a unit, your camera moves up to them, which is simply annoying. You then have to keep moving your camera all over the place because it seems like the game wants you to have full awareness of your team. "Juarez? You selected Juarez? Here he is, look! Look closer! See? That's Juarez! Want him to move over there? Okay! Lawrence too? Good! But let us just take a look at him! Oh my, how well positioned he is right here! Now go move your camera back!"This game is quite good for on-the-go casual gaming, but definitely NOT for someone who's looking for some real squad-tactics game. The tactics you employ to win this game are basically, in order of priority: 1-Put soldier behind cover; 2- If enemy is still alive, throw grenade; 3-Win game.The soundtrack is good, it fits in nicely.The graphics are fine, nothing to complain about.The camera movement is "meh". In addition to what's been already mentioned above, sometimes the action camera is badly positioned and you can't really see what's going on, but that's not gamebreaking.The real problem is charging US$15 for a game that seems poorly optimised for PC and with little replay value. Frozen Synapse costs roughly less than two times this price but brings you four times more entertainment.Luckily I got this through Humble Bundle though, phew!

												A fun game to play around with for a few hours that has limited replayability. This is a tactical strategy game that has you take command of a 4-person team that "breaches and clears" small areas. You command each unit individually, controlling things like their exact movement patterns, which way they will face, equipment to use, and so on. Has a huge amount of superficial depth, meaning that there is a ton of stuff to the game that doesn't really seem to impact it all that much, like unit stats. My unit with the worst reaction time, worst accuracy, and using the weakest gun would regularly clear out rooms of 2-4 enemies effortlessly, while my unit specially designed to kill enemies would fail to kill a single enemy out in the open. Despite this, it's definitely worth picking up and playing around with if deeply discounted.

content:
Posted: December 4, 2014
												Breach and Clear is not the kind of game you would expect it to be, walk into room, shoot things, kill things is what you would have expected to be doing with your time on Breach and Clear, but as soon as you begin the training mission it becomes very apararent that storm into a run guns blazing is not the only way to do things. You get to create a squad from seven different military forces (SAS, Seals, Spetznaz etc) and create the characters from scratch naming them and giving them a specific role within the team (medic, team leader, weapons sergeant etc) and as you play missions with them they earn XP and level up, you then earn points which you allocate to a specific skill tree on that character, relatively simple to anyone who has played a game about gear or character progression. The game is very user friendly, after playing the short 5 minute tutorial I felt like an expert, the key important features and commands you can issue to your squad are used repeatedly in the tutorial to get you used to them and the features that arne't reinforced are very easily and quickly learned, whether you want that soldier to go in that door or one soldier to throw a flashbang then the other storm the room and take out the hostiles, if you want to do it you can! Another feature that makes this game well worth the money (grab it for $3.50 now while you can) is the endless replayability, make new squads then replay each mission on the hardest difficulty experimenting with the different mechanics each time you play it!Overall Breach and Clear is quite frankly perfect, there is nothing wrong it in my eyes which earns it a 10/10

content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												Basically, it's a simplified version of Frozen Synapse. It's tons of fun and very well polished for a mobile port. Most things in this game are done right, but there are a few huge flaws about that keep it from greatness. First off, there's no multiplayer mode... Really!? A turn-based strategy has no multiplayer gamemode!? Secondly, the camera controls are a bit wonky. You'll get accustomed to it, but it just feels off. Finally, there isn't a story. You're just dropped into singleplayer missions. There are 3 game modes and about about 95 missions in all, which will give you about 15 hours of game time, but they dont have much replayability, so once you play them, then they're done... I got it in the humble bundle and I can say it was easily worth that price. If you enjoy games like XCOM: Enemy Unknown, Frozen Synapse, or Jagged Alliance, then you have no excuse to not buy this game.So, lets review.Pros:+Great addicting gameplay+Large amount  of character and squad customization+Decent visuals for a mobile port+Good AI (on Hard and up)+Large amount of missionsCons:-No story-Wonky controls-No multiplayer (Seriously?!)-Missions can get repetitive-Is a mobile port Overall, I give this game a 7/10.

												Bottom line is, that this is a fun game.The downside is that it lacks complexity and gets old pretty quickly.  Sure, it's fun going through the missions and leveling up your team in their respective specializations and getting them new gear - but then what?It's completely satisfying watching your team burst through a door and open up a can of whoopass on some unsuspecting misfits.  One of my main complaints about the gameplay, which may be a bit strange, but here it is:  You can see almost everything.  The only thing I have to wonder about is where the enemies are standing and which direction they are facing.  Surely things could be more interesting if I had a kind of blueprint of the building, and some not-so-trustworthy intel about what objects and obstacles may be where.  There's no peeking through windows or tiny spy cameras to get a better idea of what's on the other side of a door - it's all just there and you know where everything is.  I like the game, but I also want there to be more variables.  I know my team can breach and clear a room in seconds and shoot at anything that isn't themselves.  I want to make more decisions than stack order, and which door to open first.

content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
												This is one hell of a game. 10/10. I love the strategy it takes to play this game; you can't just hand this game over to anybody and expect them to do great, there is a big learning curve that comes easily and will allow you to control every aspect of your characters. Not only do you tell your soldiers where to move, but also what path to take to get there, and what direction to face every step of the way. The character skills customization really allows you to get attached to your favorite characters and mourn when they die, permanently. The perma-death is an option though so you can choose how hard this game is for you and how strategic you have to force yourself to be. The controls are simple, but some of them you have to learn for yourself that the tutorial does not cover, like how not to open the door when you approach it and how to choose your path. Every mission earns you money and experience based on difficulty, speed, and overall skill and you spend that money equipping your squad with new weapons, attachments for your weapons, face masks, helmets, armor, clothing, and even the equipment they bring into the field. There are always multiple ways to complete a mission, and there is no set way of doing anything, you choose it all. I highly recommend this game to those looking for a great squad-based tactical game, to the fans of the XCOM and Shadowrun games, and anyone else who wants a game like this. If you want a typical FPS, control over just one character, or skill-less combat then I do not recommend this game to you.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												It's a port from mobile. The enemy AI is kind of a joke and you have no way to tell your guys to hold fire. They spray lead at everything in their view instead of waiting to get in to a superior position. This often leads to them taking unnecessary damage and is tactically idiotic. Example: 4 tango with backs to entry point. Your team enters and opens fire as soon as they enter while moving to cover. They kill all 4 tangos but take damage in the exchange of gunfire. Had they held fire till in cover, they would be far less likey to take damage while maintaining their advantage of surprise and position.Game lacks "go codes" like Door Kickers does so well. In the planning stage, there is no time representation so you can't see how many seconds it will take to move someone to a position. No hold position/delay for X time command. No shoot at this target till threat is removed, then continue with plan. You can't pick which targets to shoot at so no way to prioritize targets. Therefore you can't tell your guys to focus the sniper standing in the open vs the shotguner in heavy cover who happends to be a bit closer.Another glaring problem is that every gun unlocked after the CTAR has not been an upgrade. Currently at 472 stars. Laughing at how many stars are required to unlock the later shotguns. Game is getting far too boring and repetitive to ever reach 1400 let alone the 2100 for the last rifle.From the Devs "The higher star guns are more for 'prestige' than anything else. They were added as    a prize for fans who wanted something out of the ordinary, so they are camouflaged or Platinum/Gold versions of earlier guns." Prestige in a single player game? Umm OK.No way to tell what is required to reach 4 stars on any given map. Every map and scenario has different requirements, but game fails to tell you what you are aiming for.  Use an item on one map, ok. Use the same item on another and lose a star but won't tell you are being deducted. Did I get 3 stars on my last try because I didn't make time or due to using an item? No Fn idea. Huge fail IMO. Not enough variety of weapons. One assault rifle after another. Outside of the of the P90, game lacks submachine guns like a variant of the MP5, MP7A1 or UMP. Guess this is due to the squads being military and not law enforcement. These are guns I would expect to find in the arsenal of a game that focuses on CQB regadless of the operators. Game is more arcade'ish than tactically sound. Glad I picked this up at 75% off.

content:
Posted: March 22, 2014
												Yes, its worth it.B&C is a turn based, squad controlling Xcom style game. But, instead of taking place in the future, it takes place in the present day, with real life missions, guns, and Spec Ops Units. In short, where as games like Xcom and Arma:Tactics are very stratgy based, I found this game to be based on "instinct". Missions took me a matter of a minute compared to an hour. I didn't think about what I was doing, I just was. And I ended up murdering everything with my squad of Zero Punctuation, Black Booker DeWitt, Chuck Norris and Duke Nukem. For $10, it is, well, worth it.I guess ill do a quick pros and cons, for the sake of putting this out there on launch day. When I spend more time with this, i'll attempt to have a good review.PROS+Fast Paced Combat. Like I said, its a welcome brake to be able to spend a few minutes in a game instead of an hour+Easy to learn. You can pick this up, spend about 10 minutes with it, and truley get it. Some may take that as a minus, but I see it as a very large plus+Amazing soundtrack, much better than CoD ghosts, and thats a $60 game.+Deep Costimzation. You can pick out your troops guns, hats, attachments, and more+Replayability. I feel like i'll be playing this for a long time due to all the different possibiltys in pathtaking+Varied maps. From Russia to Mexico, the missions felt different. More than I can say about most games.+Decent Port. In two hours, i got one gamebreaking bug. On hour one. GG+Fun. It seems like endless fun to go all Real Life and say "Contact Down"!!!Cons-Bad UI in menus. Seems to be better suited to the tapping of a tablet than clicking of a mouseNo real other gripes exept a few things that didnt make it from the IoS version.I'd give it a solid 9/10. Its $9($15 off sale) Buy it, you wont regret it.

content:
Posted: November 22, 2016
												Like a simpler version of Doorkickers that uses turns instead of real-time. Unfortunately the amount of time a turn is, or what will happen during said turn, is never explained. As far as I can tell the turns end once all your characters are done moving.Its very much a weird mix of XCOM in the way your characters (or "operators" if you prefer) gain perks as they level up, and a weird mix of Doorkickers in regards to position and movement. The movement is controlled by the same button that moves the camera around, so prepare to accidentally swoosh the camera across the map instead of moving your unit a lot.The orders you can give your units are extremely simple. Move, move at this speed, look this direction, or use a perk/inventory item. That's all. There is no synching up actions to "go-codes" as in Doorkickers. I guess you could synch up actions by just doing them in the same turn but depending on the stats of your units things might not happen at the same time.Speaking of stats, you can slap all sorts of tacticool♥♥♥♥♥♥all over your units and their weapons. Each thing will affect the weapon or "operator" in someway, but it usually just ends up being "+3 to Accuracy."Probably my biggest gripe with this game is how hard it tries to be high-speed low-drag hooah operators operatin' operationally. From the intro cutscene to the voice lines to the unit photos it tries so hard to be gruff and tacticool that it just ends up coming off as comical, almost a parody. But I could only listen to what sounded like a teenager saying "AREA SANITIZED" so many times before it stopped being funny.This might be fun for an hour or so, I picked it up for 99% off. I couldn't see myself getting this for more than a few dollars.

content:
Posted: February 5
												Dont buy this rage inducing game. Its fun and addicting but then it screws you over and crashes, freezes the screen, locks up your computer, or FREEZES AND DELETES ALL YOUR F***ING DATA AND PROGRESS. This happens way to often, usually in the middle or at the end of a round, and to top it all off, ITS A MOBILE PORT. JUST F***ING LOVELY.Update:Ok now that I have calmed down, let me actually give a good reason why I have given a negative review. First off, graphics. Now I know graphics don't make a game great, or terrible, but the graphics here are the same on mobile. Don't expect anything super pretty. Onto the game itself, the gameplay is very addicting, satisfying, challenging, and fun, as you go through a variety of different situations in multiple locations. There are multiple CTU's to choose from like the JTF2 (thanks for adding that btw) and the SAS along with a bunch of American CTUs and the Spestnaz and some German one that I can't remember the name of. There are also multiple guns, attachments, and perks, with six different classes and various things to upgrade. Now my main problems with this game are the small bugs. I've had a few soldiers downed because the A.I shot a long range wall bang (one end of the map to the other, specifically happening in the Germany campaign) and also when a terrorist dies, the body of the terrorist sometimes goes through a wall, which for me, greatly breaks immersion. I've also seen bullets fly right through people without doing any damage. And as noted previously in my rage, I've experience multiple crashes and lock ups, but I found out that apparently it had something to do with skype being open (my progress being deleted is still bulls***). I still can't really recommend this unless it's on sale, as I'm sure there are other games that have done this better, like door kickers, which I have yet to play (but from what I've seen it looks better, not just graphically, but gameplay-wise as well). If the dev team ever updates this again, maybe fix a few bugs and update the graphics so they look better than on mobile, or add steam workshop support for custom levels and gameplay and graphical tweaks.

												I do like this game but I feel it's missing a lot. Too much infact that I kept thinking this is in Early Access. It's your average turn-based combat game but it feels quite bare compared to something like Frozen Synapse. I was expecting to be able to fully control waypoints and time everything so that the squad performs a lot more efficient, but at the moment as far as I'm aware I can only set where the soldier goes and which way he looks and that kind of feels repetitive and not very tacticool. Also there are about 7 regiments of special forces but you can only have 4 squads which is kind of disheartening. It's not only the gameplay I wish they'd improve, the game still has quite a few bugs. The Skullcap which is a piece of headgear doesn't fit many of the soldiers and needs some adjustment which makes it unusable unless you're used to half the soldier's head poking out of it. It has bugs and like I said it's missing a lot of potential. But it is massively addictive. I only recommend this game just by an inch.

content:
Posted: October 4, 2014
												Before I bought this game I had a quick scroll through reviews and most seemed to be one of two things.  This game is so much like X-COM  OR  This game is nothing like X-COM. I agree with the latter. Both games feature turn-based tactical combat and squad customisation but that is where the similarities end. Instead of individual turns for squad members, you plan out the paths for your men, then you press the breach button and each soldier runs forth like a human weapon, pouring shots into balaclava-clad enemies. Each planning phase takes minutes but the actual real time mission plays out in a matter of seconds.I started up the game and was presented with a choice of various world special forces to play as; each with their own minor differences. I chose the SAS because it was the obvious choice (who wouldn't want to be the SAS). You get to travel to various parts of the world conducting three different brands of mission. You kill terrorists, you defuse a bomb and kill terrorists, you kill terrorists. Despite the lack of variation between the mission types the different environments are fun and the basic narratives provided give you some context as to why you are shooting these terrorists/seperatists/diisgruntled blokes. There is a rudimentary leveling up system in which you can upgrade the various skills of each of your 4 squad mates including their class specific skills. The game also has two currencies. You gain star ratings for missions and stars unlock new missions and new guns while silver allows you to buy new weapons, weapon customisations, aesthetics, new gear and consumables. It's simple system but works rather well.TL:DR -+ Be the SAS+ Bring Freedom to Heathen Terrorists+ 8.5/10- No ability to stab people from the shadows- Not enough Content

												If you are looking for deep tactical gameplay (as this game is advertised), then stay away, you won't find that here.That said, the game still offers good casual entertainment, if you enjoy leveling up your guys and unlocking new equipment, give it a spin.Quick run-down of the gameplay if you need help deciding if it is for you:You first create a squad, you can decide between some well-known specops units like DEVGRU, SAS, KSK and so on. What unit you select decides the starter attributes of your guys, one will have their special ability trained up nice, other will have reaction time up, other accuracy etc.Then you run through the missions, and I really mean run, as once you discover the one tactic that works 100% of the time against the AI, you'll just breeze through. Not much depth here, and the occasional weird glitch with your guys running backwards or facing a wall for no good reason.Your guys gain experience, and you get money, so in-between you level up your guys (in the end, it doesnt matter much what squad you made, they'll all end up the same just look different), buy them some new weapons and gear.You can upgrade weapons to modify their stats, but here you'll end up again with all the same upgrades as there is one good combination.Sounds like not much, but it is a decent enough time-killer, pick it up when it is on sale.In case 3d is not that important to you, I'd suggest to take a look at 'Door Kickers', that one has tactical gameplay down to perfection.

content:
Posted: March 23, 2014
												As of now, there are two types of war game:Everything else, and Breach & Clear. A turn based strategy game that handles the turns swiftly enough to make it feel intense, Breach & Clear puts you through the ringer around every corner. After spending a day or more customising every single aspect of your squad (from face to name to clothes, weapons, armor, and more,) you won't ever experience more abject sadness as you will when one of your turns sees your guy get killed.  Featuring what they call "Permadeath," when you lose a guy in this game, he stays down. Forever. His name, picture, and stats will be listed alongside all of your fallen warriors under the "memorial" tab of the main menu. Multiple locations and game modes, as well as different classes for your squad, see the replayability of this game stay extremely high. I would say 10 stars out of 5 if it worked like that. Since it doesn't, a definite 5 out of 5.

Breach & Clear is a deep tactical strategy simulation. Build your Special Operations team, plan and execute advanced missions, and own every angle. Choose your real-world squad -- US Army Rangers, Germany's KSK, Canada’s JTF2, UK SAS, and more -- and take on a variety of foes with different skill-sets and abilities. Learn to approach, engage, and dominate your opponents through superior tactics and training. The Steam version of Breach & Clear includes all the premium content from the original mobile game at no additional cost. - Recommended!

content:
Posted: March 24, 2014
												Great little game. I played the heck out of it on Android, and decided to get this on Steam even though I basically completed the game on Android. Decent PC port I'd have to say, though it is a fairly basic game as far as PC games are concerned with a focus on gameplay.I'd compare it most to Frozen Synapse, though this with a real-life visual interface makes it better for me and it is also much less complex to get into. Some elements of XCOM thrown in for good measure as well. Lots of content, that's one thing for sure. To merely complete all the missions (7 locations, five maps per location, 3 scenarios per map), you have 105 missions to play. Which is a lot. Missions aren't super long. The earlier maps are smaller, while as you progress they get much bigger.Lots of different weapons customization, and the 5-point difficulty scale adds quite a significant amount of depth to the game. There are six different classes, though I must admit I never fully utilized each class to its advantage in the mobile version so this is something I seek to correct on my current PC playthrough.At the end of the day, Breach & Clear is a game that would delight tactical strategy gamers. It can be played in short bursts, rewards planning (and risks) and has a lot of content to offer. So much of content I am sure you'll never play all the levels in the game! $15 may be a tad too high an asking price, but the $10 it is on launch sale now seems like a good trade-off. Recommended!

												Solid tactical shootymans action, playable on old and underpowered hardware.  Design is tight and levels are short, if it took less time to load and exit I'd call it a coffee-break game. If you played X-COM Enemy Unknown/Within and thought the battles needed to be shorter and tighter, give this one a shot.The main draw for most people is probably going to be gun porn, there are dozens of gun and gear options, most of which only require the money you get from clearing missions.  Additional guns, however, are unlocked by scoring well on those missions.  It's a cumulative thing, so if you do horribly on 10-20 missions, you get the same gun as if you did great on five missions.  And of course you can replay the missions to get better rankings.Sound design is nothing to write home about. Guns go bang (or more of a clank when suppressed), terrorists go ow, your soldiers deliver canned soundbites, music is the generic vaguely patriotic military score.  It doesn't interfere with the experience.

												The game is fantastic, just like I expected. I personally don't have an iOS or Android device, so I wasn't able to play the game prior to its PC release.This game simulates rapid close quarter engagements from a top down view. You as the player controls a squad of elite counter-terrorist forces. Using careful movement and tactics, your goal is to move throughout a building complex and eliminate all hostiles as fast as possible.The different factions you can play as gives me a really nice immersive feel when I give my men orders. It's not just an aesthetic thing either, every faction has a different stat bonus. For example, the British SAS specializes in Evasion.If you're looking for a good top-down tactical shooter (or disappointed with Black Ops II's Strike Force missions), this is most definitely for you. Do not jump into this game thinking you can force your men in rooms like supermen and expect them to go gun blazing, killing terrorists.My only gripe with this game is that the game freezes up my computer during the after action reports, forcing me to use task manager to close the game. Devs, get this nuisance out of the way, periodically update it with new content, and you have yourself a AAA quality indie game.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												Breach & Clear is a tactical strategy game that puts you under the command of a squad of soldiers from various forces from around the world, such as the SAS or Army Rangers. (Note that there is a Frozen Synapse DLC, which adds a squad, a new location and few missions from what i know, but i don't own it so i can't say much about it.)TL:DR - Skip to ConclusionREVIEW:There are 3 modes, a Terrorist Hunt (where you hunt down and kill all enemies in the area), Bomb Defusal (pretty straight forward), and Escape Plan (you're surrounded by enemies and you have get your men out of there and to the marked exit). There are a total of around 6 locations from around the world, and there are 5 missions for each location, for each mode. It works in "phases", or turns, where you can plan your squad's actions, from where they move and face, to throwing a flashbang in a room while the rest of the team storms in. Early in the game in the first three or so locations, the game is relatively easy, and having two men with suppressors enter a room first to not alert everyone, then bring in the other two when the sh-t hits the fan. There is, on occasion, situations in the Escape Plan mode where a soldier or two will be put in situations surrounded by 3+ enemies making it impossible to escape with them, it's fixable by exiting to the menu, and restarting the mission, but it can be a hassle sometimes. Missions tend to get repetitive.At the time of writing this, I have only reached the fourth location and it's become tougher than the first three, so it can provide a decent challenge, at least on higher difficulties, as i only play on normal. The game includes different roles for your squad members (The names of each role escapes me, i apologise) which can help in different situations, and  you can level them up using XP from completed missions, and you can give them bonus stats to the Accuracy, or the amount of Health they have. Oh, and there's a perma-death option which grants bonus XP. The game also offers customisation, allowing you to change your squad's clothing, camo, armour, and weapons. You can do this with the in-game money you earn from completing missions. The weapons all have available attachments which you can customise to give bonuses, like Accuracy +9001, for example. Despite this, there's a balance, where body armour which gives Health +35 will be balanced by making your movement speed go down. When breaching into rooms you have options for different entry points and different methods of breaching; Kicking the door, shotgun, breaching charge, and lock pick. Each offers an advantage and disadvantage, but i'd recommend just kicking the door open instead.The graphics, animation, and game design are pretty well done for what it is, considering it was also originally made for iOS, with Android somewhere down the line. The game offers two viewing angles while planning, a Top-down view, and an Isometric view, personally i like the top-down view better when planning because its easier to see where you moving your men. After you've finished planning and started the phase, you can view an over-the-shoulder cam of either of your soldiers, which is pretty neat, although sometimes when behind cover you wont see anything. It's there that you'll also notice how the graphics aren't as great as the would be when you're planning in t-d or iso view. There are some neat effects, and slow motion queues, which i can't say look amazing but it's tolerable. Additionally, the animations arent too great, especially when breaching and using a lock pick, as the soldier will be picking at the air or the middle of the door, as well as having their gun floating in front of them whilst doing so.CONCLUSION:Gameplay:+Multiple game modes+Different locations+Stealthable missions (for some)+/- Mission difficulty-Escape Plan mode-Repetitive missionsVisuals:+Decent textures+Effects+Different camera angles-AnimationsOverall it's a good game, with decent visuals, good gameplay, more than one game mode, etc. Coming from a more casual standpoint, for a tactical, strategy based game, it's definitely worth a buy, and if you can get it on sale even better. If you're a more "hardcore strategist" or prefer more robust strategy games, then it may not be worth it to you.

Posted: August 31, 2015
												Solid tactical shootymans action, playable on old and underpowered hardware.  Design is tight and levels are short, if it took less time to load and exit I'd call it a coffee-break game. If you played X-COM Enemy Unknown/Within and thought the battles needed to be shorter and tighter, give this one a shot.The main draw for most people is probably going to be gun porn, there are dozens of gun and gear options, most of which only require the money you get from clearing missions.  Additional guns, however, are unlocked by scoring well on those missions.  It's a cumulative thing, so if you do horribly on 10-20 missions, you get the same gun as if you did great on five missions.  And of course you can replay the missions to get better rankings.Sound design is nothing to write home about. Guns go bang (or more of a clank when suppressed), terrorists go ow, your soldiers deliver canned soundbites, music is the generic vaguely patriotic military score.  It doesn't interfere with the experience.

												Really fun squad-based strategy game. Says what it has and has what it says. Although the maps aren't randomly generated, there are quite a lot of them, and each time you play a mission on a given map the enemy placement is randomized, so there's solid replay value here. Building your squad is fun, and permadeath (which is option, but gives you a massive XP boost if you activate it) makes your decisions carry weight. Gun customization for your squad members is extensive; MUCH more than I'd have expected from a game of this type. Everything from the sights to the gas system to the trigger of every individual gun can be customized to suit your squad members' strengths.In summary, excellent game. It can be even better, and I hope one day they'll make a game with procedurally generated missions, perhaps with an even greater variety of objectives. But even as it stands right now, this game was worth the price in my opinion.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												It's the best thing out there for a room clearing CQB sim right now (at least until Door Kickers comes out).  The mechanics and engines are tight.  The character classes, skill development and kit building keep the gameplay interesting.  Each campaign has a distinct art style, and later campaigns introduce increasingly tricky scenarios including armored enemies, outdoor terrain, and entrenched marksmen.The main downside is that I wish there was a narrative to it.  Each campaign is really just a set of five maps with the same art style.  You unlock campaigns as you go, and can bounce around as you please.  It's nothing like Frozen Synapse where the missions are plot driven.As for other wishlist items, I'm sure destructable terrain would have been a pain to implement, but could have really changed gamplay.  There's also no multiplayer mode (like you'd even be able to find players for such a niche game?)  It's kinda strange you can't break-up or shuffle team-members short of getting somebody killed.  Having to build and separately level full teams is a grindy proposition should the player want to go that route.For those unfamiliar with room-clearing, a more theory based tutorial might be better.  The devs designed the game to reward actual room-clearing tactics.  In room-clearing, the objective is to stay on the attack while not getting shot in th back.  If you're constantly camping behind cover, (like every-other game with a cover-dynamic encourages), you're not getting it.  Get away from the fatal funnel, stay agile, and learn how to sweep geometries.  If a room looks scary, toss grenade/flashbang before you breach.  Unlike the old Rainbow Six or the SWAT series, there's no incentive for restraint in this game (RoE, neutrals, civilians, surrendering enemies), so let the grenades fly.All in all, it's good little single-player indie tactics game.  It's worth you time if you'd dig a fairly authentic room-clearing sim.

												Game is really fun and addicting. If you're a big fan of S.W.A.T. raids or just overall special forces raids in bases then this is the game for you. Customization is good and acceptable. Posted: January 15, 2015
												Breach & Clear is a tactical turn based strategy game similar in execution to XCOM. You take command of a special forces squad of your choosing, and plan your attack on objective based missions (terrorist hunt, bomb defusal or extraction). You have a reasonably wide selection of weapons available, though weapons used by some special forces are absent from the game. Enemy engagements are always lethal, as there is no option to simply incapacitate. The inability to set timings is also detrimental to tactics.Overall the game is entertaining enough to keep you playing for hours, but it lacks scope and depth in comparison to tactical predecessors such as Deadline (1996, Millennium Interactive). The graphics and audio are good, but I'd like to see some destructability, and a greater range of weapons and consumables (no smoke grenades or CS gas?).7/10 - Still playing it.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												Let me begin by saying that this game is alright. There isn't anything seriously bad about it, but there isn't much that is great either. I bought this game during a sale for less than $5.00 and I don't think I would have paid more for it. It's fun little game, but it feels just a step above a java game that you could play on your browser. It's pretty addicting just like some of those simple games are as well. I haven't played a game like this before, but I hear that there are similar ones with more depth. --WHO THIS GAME IS FOR--Someone who is just interested in some casual tactical gaming. Pleased enough with moderate strategy gaming.The Good: ++Levels aren't dreadfully long (about 6 minutes) but there are 7 countries to visit, each with 5 levels to play in. Also 3 game modes (Terrorist Hunt, Bomb Defusal, and Escape Plan) using same maps, This may not seem like alot but it manages to have just enough variety++There are a lot of options with costomization and I've found myself really thinking about my purchases for guns. --However, there is a problem with costomization that I will get into later++Option to play with Permanent death of squad members to earn extra XP (You get a replacement if one dies but you have to rank them back up) You keep the dead members expensive weapon equipment, which is good. ++Upgrading skills for your soldiers is pretty solid with the variety of options (Responce, Accuracy, Health, Speed, Evation and an Skill that goes with the soldier's role; Like Squad Leader gets leadership skill you can upgrade). Not too easy to upgrade but not too hard. ++I like that you can assign roles to your 4 person squad (Leader, Medic, Breach, ect) and that they get perks unlocked as you level up. The Bad: I'm going to begine with the costomization options++There are MANY different guns (some same price and same specs though) On the guns you can pack them with Optics, Lasers, Grips, Flashlights, Supressors, Gas System, and TriggersThe problem is that There are only a handful of attatchments in each category and it's easy to max out on the Optics, Lasers, Grips, Flashlights. There are no tactical thinking involved in these options because they only improve accuracy and have no negatives, so you don't weigh your options. -It's pretty mindless--The good thing is that Suppressors, Gas Systems,  and Triggers provide certain pros and cons that make you consider what perks you want and the expense of something.There are vests and other things but to buy that are important, but there are many items like clothing, goggles and facepaint that provide NO perks. ++The Main Menu is slow and kinda laggy and brings a bad first impression when you put your mouse over a button and it takes 3 seconds for it to light up. The response when you select it is absolutely normal. But makes the game seem cheap. ++The strategy is pretty basic. I've only felt trapped and in trouble a few times. The gameplay is mostly all about keeping your guys near cover and know how to split up your guys (which isn't challenging) If you 4 star all the maps as you progress Like I do and not jump ahead two counties (with harder soldiers) it doesn't stay very challenging. (I went two counties ahead and within two moves I was surounded and lost a guy right when he got shot at) -RIP Brett Breachers ++I'm playing the levels in Germany, (which is the 4th country) and the environment is pretty static. Only a few levels actually had 1-3 of the soldiers walking around in real time as you plan out your strategy. THE UGLY++The ugly part isn't in the gameplay. It is with selecting items in the market and selecting the items when you choose a new gun or add attatchments. +The interface with the Market and costomization is terrible. +When I purchase a new gun I have to make sure to detatch everything on the previous gun, and there isn't any fast/easy way to do it (Such as putting a small 'x' in the corner). I have to select the icon individually for Lasers, Optics, Grips ect. THEN select to 'unequip' this gets very Tedious when there are 7 attachment types. +The interface only shows you the picture of what items are attached to your gun with no name of them or what their specs are. +You have to go to unequip it and then mouse over it to view its specs. +Another problem is that it doesn't tell you the name of what gun your soldier is equiped with. You have to memorize its shape and look in the market so you can compare it to a new weapon. +When you want to compare weapons in the market you can't do it side by side. You have to click the gun, then scoll down/up the list to view the next one. That is teious as well. CONCLUSION:I give the game a 6.5/10 -Would not pay $15.00, wait for a sale of less than $7 if you aren't sure about this. Addicting to play but almost too simple to call it a strategy game. +It needs improvements to make the game more interesting and needs its interface to be changed. +Would be interesting to add multiplayer of terrorists vs Spec Ops. Where each team has to make their moves and then it plays out. +Another request would be to add new scenarios (This might be later in the maps, IDK yet) with a less static environment and enemies. Like Helicopter, or enemies driving in the stronghold with vehicles.

Posted: January 23, 2015
												This was one of the most addicting games I've ever played. I usually don't like this style of game and I wasn't expecting much when I purchased it, but I was quite impressed.The amount of customization is enough to keep you occupied for hours. There are several special forces factions to choose from, each having a minor stat boost to differentiate from the others. You can customize every soldier in your squad, unfortunately you do have to pick from premade looks but there's so many that it's not that big of a deal. After you've given your soldier his look you can pick one of the classes/roles, each having their own bonuses and skills that unlock as you level the soldier up. Then there is gun customization, there are a lot of guns to choose from, though it can take a while to unlock some of them. Unfortunately most of the guns are just different versions of the same gun with different stats. Furthermore you can equip scopes, lasers, flash lights, triggers, grips, and even change the gas system. After you have your soldiers outfitted with guns there are several helmets, vests, camos, etc. to choose from. It's really amazing for such a small game to have customization that rivals games like Battlefield.The gameplay is fun and thoughtful planning is your best weapon. Once you get a handle of the game the earlier difficulty levels can become sort of a faceroll, but don't worry there's multiple difficulty levels and you can tell a difference on each one. If you want to make it even harder on yourself you can select the permanent death option which is exactly as it sounds, contrary to the regular mode where your soldier will just be out of that battle but back again after the mission is over. I've always been a fan of hardcore modes in games so this was a great feature for me, though it caused me some pain a few times when I had almost max level soldiers die, then had to replace them with a fresh level 1.My only issue with the game is there is I guess you could say an "OP" gun. I will not list which gun this is as I don't want to ruin anyones experience with the game. But once I outfitted all four of my soldiers with this gun the game was too easy even on the hardest difficulties. All in all, a surprisingly impressive game. 9/10

content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
												TL;DR: Great light strategy game that will be very addicting for the first few hours for most. In a nutshell, it is a turn based strategy game in which you must complete levels to unlock new and better stuff, to be able to accomplish new and harder levels! Standard procedure really.Breach and Clear (B&C) is a port of what was original a mobile game (IOS, Android). It does have added content, however its origins still show through its simpicity. The graphics are decent and hold up to HD displays. but this the main improvement. It depicts multiple representations of real world Special Operations groups in a variety of environments, with the player being the commander that holds an eagle eye of the battlefield. The authenticity of much of the info in the game (such as the loading screen tips) is indeed relevant and true to modern day SOF, although the "tactics" the game pushes aren't necessarily completely accurate due to the reliance on user input of what to do.Technical Performance: Although I am running this on "gaming" (albeit aging) hardware, it should hold up on almost any machine at a very nice framerate. There's really nothing intensive computationally in the game. Loading times between levels  are minimal. The only adjustable settings in the graphics section are antialiasing (up to 8x), game resolution/full screen, and vsync.Starting out: There are 7 factions (squads) that you can choose from to customize, each with their own unique skill boosts. There's no context on why one might be better than the others, so it's essentially just luck. There's no reason to slave over the decision, I'd recommend just picking the squad you think looks the best aesthetically. You then select from a multitude of soldier types to fill your squad. This decision matters quite a bit as each has its own special abilities that have huge value on the battlefield. As long as you pick a variety (one of each), again don't think too hard about it. Afterward, you go through a relatively short tutorial that shows off the game's mechanics and basic strategies. Very easy to pick up, unlike some strategy games that overload my brain (and processor) from the get-go. Entertainment value: I personally wore out most of the game around 10 hours, going through every mission (7 total) and sub level (5 per mission, making 35 total playable stages without DLC) at first on normal difficulty then attempting them on insane. I've found that insane generally is actually quite doable for the most part, although on some levels (especially on the "escape plan" gamemode) they are quite impossible to perfect. There are 3 game modes: terrorist hunt (eliminate all hostiles), bomb defusal (reach and defuse one or two bombs), and escape plan (get as many squads members as possible to a position on the map). Each gamemode reuses the same missions and sub-levels, however the initial position of your soldiers varies. The reuse of the stages does get tiring eventually, but each stage provides enough enough entertaininment for a few plays. At the end of each sub level, player performance is rated on a scale of 1-4 stars, 4 being perfect or somewhat close to it. Criteria (as far as I can tell) is the time spent and how many squad members went down during the course of the sub level (this is the larger of the two criteria). Stars actually matter as they unlock the ability to purchase new guns (all accessories and gear are unlocked at default. Completion of a sub level also awards a certain amount of money, which can be spent on better equipment (guns, gear, etc). -As a little side note, it's interesting to see B&C incorporating a lot of big name brands into the game, such as but not limited to Crye Precision, Tyr Tactical, and Surefire. Even if the company doesn't have a nod, their equipment is still featured (LBT 6094, Giessele triggers, and a LOT more). This defintely is a seldom-seen feature that adds a authenticity. One of the flaws I see in the game is the lack of thought as far as gun and equipment upgrades. It's somewhat 2-Dimmensional, as there is often a clear "X plate carrier is better than Y plate carrier in every category". It seems almost carelessly done, as it significantly dims the strategic value of many purchases. In the end, out of the 18 long rifles featured, I purchased maybe 10 of them, skipping from the default rifle (M4 carbine) to some of the higher end guns by patience and thriftiness.  Gameplay: Quite fun, but reptitive after everything worth buying is unlocked. Each turn is worth 5 seconds, and works in a way similar to Fire Emblem. You start each sub level by picking from 1-4 entry points that your troops can breach through, and work your way to the objective. Each soldier has a movement range, effective firing range, etc depending on their stats and equipment, so each squad member has the potential to be very diffferent from the next. Sub level design is actually quite thorough, albeit somewhat linear at times. Usually, there are a few ways to approach an objective, through different paths. Object placement is realistic, and although this sometimes does not work out tactically, the developers really try their best to keep gameplay relatively balanced. Experimenting with new unlocks in different situations also adds to replayability, however in the end there's really only a couple of guns that players might choose to switch betweeen as they are superior to all others. I feel that some of the elements of the game, such as stealth, do not matter in the end. The developers seemed to have added them in as they are viable in real life, but the way the game works makes it relatively ineffective and I end up shooting my way through every mission anyway. Plot: There is no plot to B&C, not really even a true attempt at one, however this works out for the game. There are 7 "missions" that take place in different countries/stages, each with 5 sub-levels that have short descriptors which are essentially formalities. User Interface: The UI is especially important for strategy games as it can be confusing for newer players who have not learned what each button does. However, B&C is a relatively simple game that, once you go through the initial tutorial, you've pretty much mastered the controls. Everything is very intuitive and well organized.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2015
												This was one of the most addicting games I've ever played. I usually don't like this style of game and I wasn't expecting much when I purchased it, but I was quite impressed.The amount of customization is enough to keep you occupied for hours. There are several special forces factions to choose from, each having a minor stat boost to differentiate from the others. You can customize every soldier in your squad, unfortunately you do have to pick from premade looks but there's so many that it's not that big of a deal. After you've given your soldier his look you can pick one of the classes/roles, each having their own bonuses and skills that unlock as you level the soldier up. Then there is gun customization, there are a lot of guns to choose from, though it can take a while to unlock some of them. Unfortunately most of the guns are just different versions of the same gun with different stats. Furthermore you can equip scopes, lasers, flash lights, triggers, grips, and even change the gas system. After you have your soldiers outfitted with guns there are several helmets, vests, camos, etc. to choose from. It's really amazing for such a small game to have customization that rivals games like Battlefield.The gameplay is fun and thoughtful planning is your best weapon. Once you get a handle of the game the earlier difficulty levels can become sort of a faceroll, but don't worry there's multiple difficulty levels and you can tell a difference on each one. If you want to make it even harder on yourself you can select the permanent death option which is exactly as it sounds, contrary to the regular mode where your soldier will just be out of that battle but back again after the mission is over. I've always been a fan of hardcore modes in games so this was a great feature for me, though it caused me some pain a few times when I had almost max level soldiers die, then had to replace them with a fresh level 1.My only issue with the game is there is I guess you could say an "OP" gun. I will not list which gun this is as I don't want to ruin anyones experience with the game. But once I outfitted all four of my soldiers with this gun the game was too easy even on the hardest difficulties. All in all, a surprisingly impressive game. 9/10

content:
Posted: February 6, 2015
												7/10Plenty of fun, but about as deep as a thimble.The Good--- Tons of fun. Extremely satisfying to clear a level of badguys in like 14 seconds of "real time"--- Just like the old Rainbow Six before they dumbed it down, (minus the Rainbow Six first-person mode)--- Passable graphics and sound. Good enough for what it is.--- Randomly generated enemy locations thwart attempts at replaying with prescience. --- Flanking seems to remove the need for dice rolls. I hate dice rolls. Strategy games should win or lose on strategy, not dice rolls.--- Levels can be replayed in a variety of different modes: Terrorist Hunt (standard), Defuse the Bomb (capture and hold), and Escape. These add a lot of really awesome replayability--- Heavily moddable equipment, but I kinda wish it were more moddable, and that there were some way to save loadouts--- Enemy AI isn't totally dumb. Uncoordinated, perhaps - but its how I would expect them to act in the face of marines kicking down the door. (Dive for cover, unload magazine at doorway)THE BAD--- Clunky User Interface, with some frustratingly annoying problems.--- No story, plot, or characters. Just a series of, what are essentially just "puzzles". Puzzles solved with guns and grenades, true... but the puzzle is always: "Get all the Marines to flank all the terrorists as quickly as possible", just with new environments each level.--- Guns are pay-to-win, which is a bit silly for a game touting its realism. I would expect realistic prices, not having guns that "unlock" when your navy seals reach a certain level, and like super-sci-fi versions from some of the company's other games--- Gameplay mechanics are more reminiscent of tabletop than real tactics. Cover can't be thwarted (except with grenades), so its all about getting baddies in a crossfire. I suppose there's nothing strictly -wrong- about this, except that (once again) it flies in the face of the vaunted realism--- A lot of the equipment is a bit silly. You might get a gas assist system that increases damage by 3 but increases noise by 3, then add a silencer that decreases noise by 3 but also decreases damage by 3. Somehow I feel that the net benefit of something should be greater, not just even-out--- Soldier customization is rather bad. You may find yourself doing the same thing over and over. Like if you want to switch out for close range for a particular level and then switch back afterward, you need to go back and replace every single item. There are no preset or savable loadouts. Depending on your level of customization, this can be quite tedious. For example: all my soldiers have helmets and armor painted black (paint applied separately), and guns with 6 unique enhancements. The guns and all the enhancements also have to be painted black (etc).IN CONCLUSIONFun, but not perfect. I really wish they'd add a plot like Splinter Cell or something. Something in-line with what they're trying to do, but make it more interesting. UI and the market/loadout could really use a lot of work. Otherwise pretty solid!

Posted: December 30, 2015
												It's fine and all, fills a niche, but it's stale and lacks obvious features. It's a bit like a 3D version of Doorkickers (worth checking out if you're considering this). The combat is turn based, let's say you were storming a room with two entrances and lined up 2 guys outside each entrance. You might conceivably want them to storm the room at the same time, but alas, no, the only way to tell if that's going to happen is with a timeline style thing which runs across the characters move path. So on the floor on the otherside of the door might say 2 seconds. Well, on that 2 second mark you might want your other team to storm in. Unbelievably, there's no way to synchronise those events, by say, telling the other guy to pause for a second before proceeding. You could get him to run in circles before going through the door I guess, but then you hardly feel like a SWAT team. Another similarly stupid mechanic is that you cant order someone to go stand where someone else is stood, even if they're going to be 4 seconds down the hall before the other guy gets there. I think the real fun stems from the customisation and the content around that. Lots of maps, lots of guns, and a combat system that is just competent enough to be fun.

I wish those levels were more true extraction, where you'd have to fight as a unit through to a waypoint.- I would prefer the ability to set a sniper in a lookout location to provide cover, but this is very minor and probably something I'd want the devs to include in a future option.- Again, something minor that would add to the game, would be if you could plan the strategy, but then control one of the team members as a FPS.- Very minor. I wish each team had their own bankroll, instead of sharing a community pool.The positives far outweight the negatives. Very fun game, and playing at multiple difficulty levels increases the replayability.**Have not played Frozen Synapse DLC yet, but plan to buy it**

												It's fine and all, fills a niche, but it's stale and lacks obvious features. It's a bit like a 3D version of Doorkickers (worth checking out if you're considering this). The combat is turn based, let's say you were storming a room with two entrances and lined up 2 guys outside each entrance. You might conceivably want them to storm the room at the same time, but alas, no, the only way to tell if that's going to happen is with a timeline style thing which runs across the characters move path. So on the floor on the otherside of the door might say 2 seconds. Well, on that 2 second mark you might want your other team to storm in. Unbelievably, there's no way to synchronise those events, by say, telling the other guy to pause for a second before proceeding. You could get him to run in circles before going through the door I guess, but then you hardly feel like a SWAT team. Another similarly stupid mechanic is that you cant order someone to go stand where someone else is stood, even if they're going to be 4 seconds down the hall before the other guy gets there. I think the real fun stems from the customisation and the content around that. Lots of maps, lots of guns, and a combat system that is just competent enough to be fun.

												Time Played: 7 hours as of this review.I caught this game while it was on sale for 5$  And that was about all I'd spend on this game.Graphically; the game uses rather dated graphics made worse by missing textures from some of it's enemies, the first few levels are the worst in that regard. Also, lacking polish in regards to the little things, one of the most clawing is the AWP sniper rifle ejecting multiple brass casings when it fires.So, graphics aren't a deal breaker nowadays, so what's the tactical gameplay like? Basic. The game features cover, breaching tactics, and grenades, All were great in X-com: Enemy Unknown, but here they feel very contrived. I have yet to find a good position for my sniper, and enemy snipers start in very good positions. Starting positions in later levels are very impractical, leaving your squad open during the most critical entry moments. Furthermore, any feature involving doors (any breaching methods, and the ability to wedge doors closed) are not even present in many missions because they take place outside, with no other 'breaching' methods to replace them. I figured outside grenades could serve as a breaching method, but many of the maps are designed in such a way that you cannot throw grenades directly out the doorway to clear yourself an opening.Which brings me to enemy placement, which is randomized. Don't get me wrong, randomization brings replayability, but unless you want to spend a fifth of your mission earnings on UAVs for each mission, then you are left with no way of knowing where even basic enemies directly at your starting position are. This turns most missions into a bloody slug-fest as you pray your soldiers can even make it in the door without dying. Especially when mexican cartel snipers are far better shots than your special forces sniper with max accuracy and loaded with high-tech targeting devices.At the end of the day, the game uses many of the tired and cheap methods of increasing difficulty that I thought we left behind in the 90s, and for me, that makes this game a far cry shy of being worth 15$.

												Solid tactical shootymans action, playable on old and underpowered hardware.  Design is tight and levels are short, if it took less time to load and exit I'd call it a coffee-break game. If you played X-COM Enemy Unknown/Within and thought the battles needed to be shorter and tighter, give this one a shot.The main draw for most people is probably going to be gun porn, there are dozens of gun and gear options, most of which only require the money you get from clearing missions.  Additional guns, however, are unlocked by scoring well on those missions.  It's a cumulative thing, so if you do horribly on 10-20 missions, you get the same gun as if you did great on five missions.  And of course you can replay the missions to get better rankings.Sound design is nothing to write home about. Guns go bang (or more of a clank when suppressed), terrorists go ow, your soldiers deliver canned soundbites, music is the generic vaguely patriotic military score.  It doesn't interfere with the experience.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 16, 2015
												While I wouldn't necessarily compare the game to X-Com, neither new nor old, it is hard not to draw some parallels, considering both are Turnbased Tactics games. Breach & Clear has more in common with Frozen Synapse than it does have in common with X-Com though.The gameplay is rather simple. Enemies are randomly seeded into a map, where they will do their terroristy things like inspecting the carpet in an otherwise empty room, and you are tasked with clearing the bad guys, finding a hostage/bomb or escaping to an exfil location. The random seeding of the enemy gives the game quite a bit of replay-ability.Each level has one or more entry points and you as the player are tasked with dividing your 4 people team among the entry points and then go from there. You plan each move in its entirety and then once you have planned it, you execute said plan. Covering all the angels, trying to use cover to your advantage or throw flashbangs or regular grenades into an area to deal with the enemy.The game's simplicity is also its strength. Nobody ever said that chess was a boring game because it had a bunch of simple rules and Breach & Clear is like that as well. You do have a couple tactical options but for the most part its simple facing, facing and positioning, that wins the day.Graphically the game isn't impressive, but being a spiritual successor to Frozen Synapse it is still a step up from a blue backdrop and green and red enemies. Also I can't quite put my finger on it, why I am liking this game more than I did Frozen Synapse, but I also couldn't name any real difference between the two other than Breach & Clear having the more appealing aesthetic.Breach & Clear also offers a class and level system, with your team getting more experienced and unlocking more abilities. And there is a shop allowing you to buy new unlocked weapons, equipment and cosmetic items.All in all a solid game with, at the very least, the early missions taking about 10 to 15 minutes tops.

												Admittedly I barely get to game these days , but  with that said I am enjoying short bursts of this game immensely . It's hardly "perfect" but  with that said it's stepping  in almost all the right directions and actually applies real life logic that you'll see any tactical course instructor  teach  during any given training day in any shoothouse across the world. no  bizzaro "game logic" applies within these missions ( just the in game "marketplace" ..that  could use some tweeks but it's the  only "game logic" moment I have encountered . )  and  all that one could hope to learn about sweep and clearing applies hereIf you are asking yourself : Which  do I  get , this XCOM Doorkickers or Frozen synapse? ..just get all 4 trust me, each has their merit .If you are like me and spend more time  practicing with  arms and equipment than playing  games... get this one FIRST. Still get all 4 though! , why miss out on great  strategy gaming? and when you're done with all of em  come back  home to the  original X-COM titles...They miss you. (but their aim is improving!)Now if this game gets a  Vs. mode more avaiable  squads from around the world ( where's my FBI H.R.T. ? ) and steam workshop support / D.I.Y. levels   in either this title or a sequel  we pretty  much have the PERFECT  modern military game..and one that the COD kiddies  will  loathe and despise ...because  "gasp" gods forbid that  they engage more than  two braincells that  don't involve flinging profanity, pathetic "trolling" ad hominems, or insults through standard TCPIP via a cheap headset .Sorry  had to .. Why are ya reading this  far?...GO BUY THIS IF YOU LIKE STRATEGY AND REAL WORLD SMALL SQUAD TACTICS! Seriously !

content:
Posted: February 7
												---Important: Game was bought in a sale---Pros:-Pretty motivating progression System with a lot of gear selection and stat editing-Gameplay is fun and offers enough gameplay depth-Graphics are decent considering the game is already a few years oldCons:-Walls do not become see-through when necessary which causes issues from time to time-Controlls (especially the menus) feel clunky-Compared the Doorkickers the game offers not as much gameplay depth (no breach options after the first door, less actions that can be ordered for a move, etc.)Overall the game is fun and I don´t regret buying it in a !sale!, I wouldn´t buy it for the current full price though. Gameplay wise I think Doorkickers is superior because it offers more options to complete a mission. On the other hand "Breach & Clear" offers a better character modification and the soldiers act more realistically (lean around corners, etc.). The same is true for the graphics which I prefer over "Doorkickers" comic look.
